articles.headline: F.B.I. Arrests National Guardsman in Leak of Classified Documents
articles.snippet: Authorities say Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old member of the Massachusetts Air National Guard, posted sensitive materials in an online chat group.
articles.abstract: Authorities say Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old member of the Massachusetts Air National Guard, posted sensitive materials in an online chat group.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on the leak of classified intelligence documents.
articles.byline: By Haley Willis, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Aric Toler, Christiaan Triebert, Julian E. Barnes and Malachy Browne

articles.headline: How Silicon Valley Bank’s Failure Could Have Spread Far and Wide
articles.snippet: New research suggests large parts of the country remain vulnerable to widespread bank failure in the event of a run on deposits.
articles.abstract: New research suggests large parts of the country remain vulnerable to widespread bank failure in the event of a run on deposits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government’s rescue of two failed banks last month has drawn criticism from some lawmakers and investors, who accuse the Biden administration and the Federal Reserve of bailing out wealthy customers in California and New York and sticking bank customers in Middle America with the bill.

articles.headline: Injuries and Illness Slow Senators, as Well as the Senate Itself
articles.snippet: High-profile absences have created complications for Democrats as Congress returns and prompted new questions about the future of Republican leadership.
articles.abstract: High-profile absences have created complications for Democrats as Congress returns and prompted new questions about the future of Republican leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A pair of high-profile absences has thrown the Senate into a state of uncertainty at a critical time, raising questions about whether Democrats will be able to conduct business and who will lead Republicans through a potentially chaotic period as they try to reclaim the majority next year.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Annie Karni

articles.headline: The Airman Who Gave Gamers a Real Taste of War
articles.snippet: A group liked online war games. But then Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old National Guard airman, began showing members classified documents, they say.
articles.abstract: A group liked online war games. But then Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old National Guard airman, began showing members classified documents, they say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on the leak of classified intelligence documents.
articles.byline: By Aric Toler, Christiaan Triebert, Haley Willis, Malachy Browne, Michael Schwirtz and Riley Mellen

articles.headline: Germany Quits Nuclear Power, Ending a Decades-Long Struggle
articles.snippet: The last three plants in Germany are scheduled to shut down by Saturday, while other European countries are looking to expand nuclear energy.
articles.abstract: The last three plants in Germany are scheduled to shut down by Saturday, while other European countries are looking to expand nuclear energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: It began as a movement of pacifists chaining themselves to fences outside nuclear power plants. Five decades later, the effort to close German nuclear power plants will end with echoes of the Cold War era in which it began, as Russia’s war in Ukraine is a reminder of both the risks and promise of nuclear energy.
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy and Erika Solomon

articles.headline: ‘The Justins’ Follow a Legacy of Resistance in Tennessee
articles.snippet: The young Black Democrats expelled from the legislature bring an activist approach, and model themselves after civil rights leaders of the past.
articles.abstract: The young Black Democrats expelled from the legislature bring an activist approach, and model themselves after civil rights leaders of the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Justin Jones arrived at the State Capitol in Tennessee as a freshly elected lawmaker representing parts of Nashville. A 27-year-old Black Democrat, he belonged to a party vastly outnumbered by a largely white Republican majority. The advice was clear.
articles.byline: By Clyde McGrady, Emily Cochrane and Jon Cherry

articles.headline: Republican 2024 Hopefuls Embrace Gun Politics at N.R.A. Meeting
articles.snippet: The current and potential 2024 presidential candidates showed strong support for gun owners’ rights — a core issue for the party’s base, but one that can be a tougher sell in a general election.
articles.abstract: The current and potential 2024 presidential candidates showed strong support for gun owners’ rights — a core issue for the party’s base, but one that can be a tougher sell in a general election.
articles.lead_paragraph: They cited Scripture and issued calls for prayer. They applauded law enforcement and demanded tighter security in schools. They lamented the nation’s mental health crisis and offered tough talk about the death penalty.

articles.headline: Unemployment Is Low. Inflation Is Falling. But What Comes Next?
articles.snippet: Despite hopeful signs, economists worry that a recession is on the way or that the Federal Reserve will cause one in trying to rein in inflation.
articles.abstract: Despite hopeful signs, economists worry that a recession is on the way or that the Federal Reserve will cause one in trying to rein in inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are two starkly different ways of looking at the U.S. economy right now: what the data says has happened in the past few months, and what history warns could happen next.

articles.headline: China’s Car Buyers Have Fallen Out of Love With Foreign Brands
articles.snippet: Domestic companies are now selling more vehicles than their multinational rivals, which have failed to keep up with Chinese consumers’ demand for electric cars and S.U.V.s.
articles.abstract: Domestic companies are now selling more vehicles than their multinational rivals, which have failed to keep up with Chinese consumers’ demand for electric cars and S.U.V.s.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, foreign automakers in China had a bead on customers drawn to luxury brands, like the Cao family in Shanghai. Not anymore.

articles.headline: Ghosts Past and Present Cross Paths as War Comes to Nuclear Wasteland
articles.snippet: Not everyone evacuated when the Chernobyl nuclear plant melted down in 1986. The few who stayed lived through another calamity when Russian troops marched in.
articles.abstract: Not everyone evacuated when the Chernobyl nuclear plant melted down in 1986. The few who stayed lived through another calamity when Russian troops marched in.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world’s worst nuclear disaster, unfolding only a few miles away, did not force Halyna Voloshyna, 74, to abandon her home in Chernobyl in 1986.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Emile Ducke

articles.headline: Biggest U.S. Banks Report Bumper Profits Amid Industry Turmoil
articles.snippet: JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Wells Fargo comfortably beat expectations for earnings in the first quarter, when the failures of smaller banks sent jitters through the sector.
articles.abstract: JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Wells Fargo comfortably beat expectations for earnings in the first quarter, when the failures of smaller banks sent jitters through the sector.
articles.lead_paragraph: The country’s largest banks escaped the crisis that just weeks ago brought down two midsize U.S. lenders, unnerving regulators and depositors. If anything, the tumult helped those giants rake in bumper profits.
articles.byline: By Rob Copeland and Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: Supreme Court Briefly Preserves Broad Availability of Abortion Pill
articles.snippet: The temporary stay is meant to preserve the status quo while the justices study lower court rulings, and it did not forecast how they would ultimately rule.
articles.abstract: The temporary stay is meant to preserve the status quo while the justices study lower court rulings, and it did not forecast how they would ultimately rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. issued an order on Friday temporarily ensuring that a common abortion pill would remain widely available while the Supreme Court considered whether to grant the Biden administration’s emergency request to preserve the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of the drug.
